programme.title: The Who: Quadrophenia - Can You See the Real Me?
programme.desc: The Who's 1973 concept album "Quadrophenia" is the focus of this rock documentary, which features insight from the band's guitarist, Pete Townshend

programme.title: Eric Clapton: I Still Do - An Intimate Discussion About Rock, the Blues, and Shepherd's Pie
programme.desc: Eric Clapton and music producer Glyn Johns talk with comedian Paul Whitehouse about their history together as well as their work on Clapton's 2016 album, "I Still Do." Also: behind-the-scenes footage of the recording process; and performances of several of the songs

programme.title: Jeff Lynne's ELO at Hyde Park
programme.desc: On a sunny day in September 2014, Jeff Lynne, head honcho of 70s hit-making band ELO, took to the stage in London's Hyde Park and, with the help of his backing band and the strings of the BBC Concert Orchestra, brought to a close Radio 2's Live in Hyde Park annual festival. After an absence from the live stage for 28 years, this headline set by Jeff Lynne's ELO was a much-anticipated and talked-about event. In front of 50,000 people, Jeff Lynne delivered a rousing and crowd-pleasing string of the Electric Light Orchestra's chart-topping hits including, Livin' Thing, Sweet Talkin' Woman, Don't Bring Me Down, Mr Blue Sky, and Roll Over Beethoven. And there was also Jeff's touching tribute to his band buddies from Traveling Wilburys, in his performance of their 1988 hit Handle With Care

programme.title: Paul McCartney and Wings: Rockshow
programme.desc: Rockshow is a filmed record of the 10-country 1976 tour conducted by Paul McCartney and his rock group Wings. The climax takes place before a crowd of 67,000 at the King Dome in Seattle. Among the songs presented by McCartney & Company are "Jet", "Band on the Run", "Maybe I'm Amazed" and "Yesterday"

programme.title: Later...With Jools Holland
programme.desc: Jools is joined by New York trio Yeah Yeah Yeahs, performing tracks from their fourth album 'Mosquito' including their current epic single, 'Sacrilege'. Also from New York, Vampire Weekend will be performing tracks from their upcoming third studio album 'Modern Vampires of the City'. Blues man Seasick Steve also appears on the show, joined by the likes of Led Zeppelin's John Paul Jones on tracks from his upcoming album on Fiction Records 'Hubcap Music'. From Birmingham, a brand new solo singer, Jacob Banks makes his TV debut and from London, one of the UK's most successful singer songwriters, Dido, plays a couple of songs from her recent fourth album 'Girl Who Got Away'. In addition to these performances, the former lead singer of The Animals, Eric Burdon, chats to Jools about his life, career and new album

programme.title: V Fest 2015

programme.title: Adele: Live in London
programme.desc: Singer-songwriter Adele performs her classic tunes, plus tracks from her album "25." She also chats with host Graham Norton

programme.title: Florence + The Machine: Live at Glastonbury Festival 2015
programme.desc: Florence and the Machine perform at the 2015 Glastonbury Festival in England. The set includes songs from the 2015 album "How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful" and past hits

programme.title: Sister Sparrow & the Dirty Birds: Live at the Fox
programme.desc: Rock-soul group Sister Sparrow and the Dirty Birds perform at the Fox Theatre in Boulder. Songs include "Sugar" and a cover of Aretha Franklin's "Dr. Feelgood."

programme.title: Live From Daryl's House
programme.desc: Allen Stone. Music guest Allen Stone joins forces with Daryl Hall, rendering a set that includes the songs "Lifetime of Love," "Laughing Down Crying" and "Ennui on the Mountain."

programme.title: Live From Daryl's House
programme.desc: Aloe Blacc. Aloe Blacc performs with host Daryl Hall

programme.title: Austin City Limits
programme.sub-title: Leon Bridges; Nathaniel Rateliff and the Night Sweats
programme.desc: Leon Bridges; Nathaniel Rateliff and the Night Sweats. It's a flow of soul music when Leon Bridges performs a set that includes songs from his 2015 album "Coming Home." In addition, singer-songwriter Nathaniel Rateliff and his band the Night Sweats take to the ACL stage

programme.title: Austin City Limits
programme.desc: Gary Clark Jr.; Alabama Shakes. Guitarist Gary Clark Jr. and the blues-rock band Alabama Shakes perform. Included: Alabama Shakes highlight their 2012 album "Boys & Girls."

programme.title: Austin City Limits
programme.desc: Avett Brothers; Heartless Bastards. Roots rockers the Avett Brothers highlight songs from their 2009 album "I and Love and You." Also: the rock group Heartless Bastards perform

programme.title: Austin City Limits
programme.sub-title: Leon Bridges; Nathaniel Rateliff and the Night Sweats
programme.desc: Leon Bridges; Nathaniel Rateliff and the Night Sweats. It's a flow of soul music when Leon Bridges performs a set that includes songs from his 2015 album "Coming Home." In addition, singer-songwriter Nathaniel Rateliff and his band the Night Sweats take to the ACL stage

programme.title: Bonnaroo Backtracks
programme.desc: Performance highlights from the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival are featured. Included: Pearl Jam; Arcade Fire; the White Stripes; My Morning Jacket; Paul McCartney; Metallica; Alabama Shakes; Macklemore and Ryan Lewis; and Lionel Richie

programme.title: Later...With Jools Holland
programme.desc: Later...With Jools Holland: Legends. A legends-theme edition features A-list artists who have appeared on the series. Included: David Bowie; the Beach Boys; David Gilmour; Gladys Knight; Steve Miller Band; Carole King; Paul McCartney; the Who; and Lou Reed

programme.title: George Fest: A Night to Celebrate the Music of George Harrison
programme.desc: The music of George Harrison is performed by his son Dhani, Brian Wilson, Ann Wilson, Norah Jones, Butch Walker, Ben Harper, Cold War Kids, Brandon Flowers and others. Recorded September 28th, 2014 at the Fonda Theater in L.A

programme.title: Carole King/James Taylor: Live at the Troubadour
programme.desc: Carole King and James Taylor reunited at the intimate Hollywood venue in concert in 2007 to play their era-defining hits, nearly four decades after they first performed at the Troubadour in November 1970, a year before their Tapestry and Sweet Baby James' albums stormed the American charts. King and Taylor are backed by the Section, the same band that propelled those albums into homes around the world

programme.title: Later...With Jools Holland
programme.desc: Joining Jools on the third show of the series and making his Later... debut is Bee Gee Barry Gibb, who will be performing a track or two from his upcoming second solo album In the Now, which he co-wrote with his sons Stephen and Ashley. Barry and his band will also treat us to one or two Bee Gees classics. Returning to the show is Norah Jones, who is on the cusp of releasing her sixth solo album Day Breaks, which finds her returning to the piano and her roots. Slaves made their debut on the show back in 2014 and return to rip through a couple of numbers from their second studio album Take Control, which was produced by former Beastie Boy Michael ""Mike D"" Diamond. Singer-songwriter Declan McKenna performs a couple of tracks from his soon-to-come debut album, which is he working on with producer James Ford. Performing solo, Lisa Hannigan has just released her third album At Swim

programme.title: Storytellers
programme.desc: Coldplay. Weeks before the much-anticipated release of their album X&Y, Coldplay took to the stage at Brooklyn Academy of Music for an intimate night of storytelling and live music. Storytellers: Coldplay gives viewers a unique opportunity to hear the inspiration and stories behind such hits as Clocks, Yellow, Politik, The Scientist, In My Place and new tracks Speed of Sound and Fix You . As well as debuting new tunes and revisiting old favourites, Chris Martin, Will Champion, Guy Berryman, and Jon Buckland also share a song they wrote for Johnny Cash ( Till Kingdom Come ). And as part of the "storytelling" part of the sold-out gig, Martin reveals that Yellow was inspired by the Yellow Pages and that Speed of Sound was an attempt to rip-off Kate Bush's Running Up That Hill

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Clemency Burton-Hill presents Radio 3's classical breakfast show, featuring listener requests and a new specially composed work by 'Composer in 3' Matthew Kaner. Including 7.00, 8.00 News. 7.30, 8.30 News Headlines

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: Rob Cowan shares more of his favourite Baroque concertos, including Handel's Op 6, and one of the Corelli set that was Handel's inspiration. At 9.30, he introduces a musical challenge to identify the location for a particular piece of music, and at 10.00, he hears from actress Noma Dumezweni, currently starring as Hermione in the West End play Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. At 10.30, Rob introduces the latest instalment of the 70-part daily series Power of Three, and then places Music in Time, and explores the works of pianist, band leader and composer Duke Ellington. At 11.00, Rob showcases more music by pianist Emil Gilels. Scarlatti: Sonata in B minor, K27. Emil Gilels (piano)

programme.title: Composer of the Week: Coleridge-Taylor
programme.desc: The composer's mixed-race heritage was unusual in Victorian Britain, but his talents as a musician seemed to protect him from much of the racism that might have been expected to come his way. However, when he fell in love with English pianist Jessie Walmisley, her family was outraged at the prospect of a `mixed marriage'. Donald Macleod tells the story of the romance between the pair and plays some of the music they worked on together. Coleridge-Taylor: Romance in G; Ballade in D minor. Rachel Barton (violin), Virginia Eskin (piano). The Lee Shore; The Sea Shell. BBC Singers, conductor Paul Brough. Spirituals - Going Up, Take Nabadji, and Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child. Virginia Eskin (piano). The Death of Minnehaha. Helen Field (soprano), Bryn Terfel (baritone), Orchestra and Chorus of the Welsh National Opera, conductor Kenneth Alwyn

programme.title: Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert
programme.sub-title: Radio 3 Big Chamber Weekend: Cedars Hall
programme.desc: Fiona Talkington presents the second in a series of four concerts created in partnership with Cedars Hall at Wells Cathedral School, in which the Atos Trio takes a musical journey around four European cities. This time, the focus falls on Paris, with music by chamber composer Jean Francaix. Next, the former Radio 3 New Generation Artists are joined by Philip Dukes for Faure's Piano Quartet in C minor, Op 15. Atos Trio, Philip Dukes (viola). Francaix: Trio in D. Faure: Piano Quartet No 1 in C minor, Op 15

This time, the ensemble tackles Elgar's In The South and Carillon as part of Afternoon on 3's British Music Season. Elgar: Overture: In the South, Op 50 (Alassio). BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, conductor Martyn Brabbins. 2.25 Brahms: Piano Concerto No 1 in D minor, Op 15. Denis Kozhukhin, BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, conductor Thomas Dausgaard. 3.10 Elgar: Carillon, Op 75. Florence Daguerre De Hureaux (reciter), BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, conductor Martyn Brabbins

programme.title: Choral Evensong
programme.desc: Canon Marcus Huxley directs a performance of devotional music from Birmingham Cathedral. Introit: Jesu, the Very Thought of Thee (Harry Grindle). Responses: Byrd. Psalms 98, 99, 100, 101 (Attwood, Ouseley, Barnby). First Lesson: Hosea 14 vv 1-7. Office Hymn: O Trinity of Blessed Light (Creator alme). Canticles: Antony le Fleming. Second Lesson: 2 Timothy 4 vv 1-8. Anthem: The Wilderness (SS Wesley). Final Hymn: Soldiers of Christ, Arise (From Strength to Strength). Organ Voluntary: Sonata No 2 - third and fourth movements (Mendelssohn). Director of Music: Canon Marcus Huxley. Assistant Director of Music: David Hardie

programme.title: In Tune
programme.desc: Suzy Klein introduces a lively mix of music, chat and arts news live from the Radio 3 Conference of Inclusion and Diversity in Composition at the Royal Northern College of Music in Manchester. Includes performances by the BBC Philharmonic conducted by John Storgards. Errollyn Wallen, Priti Paintal and Shiva Nova, Raymond Yiu, American composer Jeffrey Mumford and students of the RNCM. Including 5.00, 6.00 News

The ensemble performs the Russian composer's dramatic Manfred Symphony, and the curious Piano Concerto No 2 in G, Op 44. Kirill Gerstein (piano), BBC Symphony Orchestra, conductor Semyon Bychkov. Tchaikovsky: Piano Concerto No 2 in G, Op 44. 8.10 Interval. 8.30 Tchaikovsky: Symphony in B minor, Op 58 (Manfred)

programme.title: Three Score and Ten
programme.desc: The 50-part series celebrating 70 years of radio poetry, from the Third Programme onwards, continues. Ian McMillan introduces one of the key poets of the 1960s, Adrian Mitchell, reading Nostalgia Now Threepence Off originally recorded for a Radio 3 broadcast in 1962

programme.title: Free Thinking
programme.sub-title: Paul Nash; George Szirtes; Hungary 1956 and Now

programme.title: The Essay: All My Presidents
programme.sub-title: The Lucky and the Luckless: Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter
programme.desc: Michael Goldfarb's revisits the cultural legacies of two more US Presidents, telling the story of the luckless Jimmy Carter and his successor, Ronald Reagan, who seemed to be blessed with abundant good fortune

programme.title: Late Junction
programme.sub-title: Fiona Talkington with a Vocal Special
programme.desc: Fiona Talkington presents a vocal special exploring the wonders of the human voice. She showcases music comes by composer and performer Jennifer Walsh, pianist Tigran Hamasyan and trumpeter Arve Henriksen, who offer their take on a vocal piece by the Armenian composer Komitas, and musical polymath Meredith Monk, ahead of her tenure as Radio 3's Composer of the Week. Plus, ambiant music by London-based multi-instrumentalists Padang Food Tigers, and a new release by Richard Dawson's new duo with Rhodri Davies, Hen Ogled

programme.title: Through the Night
programme.desc: Catriona Young presents a selection of classical music to take listeners through to the early hours. Bruch: Violin Concerto No 1 in G minor, Op 26. programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Clemency Burton-Hill presents Radio 3's classical breakfast show, featuring listener requests and another chance to hear this week's new piece by Composer in 3 Matthew Kaner. Including 7.00, 8.00 News. 7.30, 8.30 News Headlines

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: With Rob Cowan. 9.00 My favourite Baroque concertos. Rob's selection includes a lively bassoon concerto by Vivaldi, a festive trumpet concerto by Torelli, and Bach's darkly intense Triple Concerto for flute, violin and harpsichord. He also chooses a pair of Concerti Grossi: the final (and Rob believes the loveliest) of Handel's, Op 6, and one of the Corelli set that was Handel's inspiration. 9.30 A musical challenge to trace the classical theme behind a track from the world of rock music. 10.00 Actress Noma Dumezweni, currently starring as Hermione in the West End play Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, chooses her favourite classical music. 10.30 Power of Three. David Hendy presents pioneering sounds from the BBC Third Programme and Radio 3 archives. Followed by Music in Time. Rob explores the music of six pioneering African and African-American composers, today focusing on organist and composer Fela Sowande (1905-1987), who is considered the father of Nigerian art music. 11.00 The artist of the week is pianist Emil Gilels. Rob celebrates the centenary of this great musician with dazzling recordings demonstrating the breadth of his repertoire, continuing with Chopin's Piano Sonata No 3 in B minor

programme.title: Composer of the Week: Coleridge-Taylor
programme.desc: Although best remembered for his choral masterpiece Hiawatha's Wedding Feast, Coleridge-Taylor was also a prolific composer of incidental music for the stage, and the chamber music that had marked him out as a remarkable student at the Royal College of Music. Donald Macleod explores some of his lesser-known music, with specially recorded performances by the BBC Singers. Coleridge-Taylor: Othello - dance. New Symphony Orchestra, conductor Malcolm Sargent. Sea Drift. BBC Singers, conductor Paul Brough. Violin Sonata. David Juritz (violin), Michael Dussek (piano). Spirituals - Deep River; Run Mary Run. Virginia Eskin (piano). Piano Quintet in G minor. Nash Ensemble. Dead in the Sierras. BBC Singers, conductor Paul Brough

programme.title: News

programme.title: Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert
programme.sub-title: Radio 3 Big Chamber Weekend: Cedars Hall
programme.desc: Fiona Talkington presents the third in a series four concerts created by Radio 3, in partnership with Cedars Hall at Wells Cathedral School, together with the Atos Trio. In today's lunchtime concert the group's musical journey around four European cities reaches St Petersburg, a jewel in Russia's architectural and musical crowns. Two members of the Atos Trio and clarinettist Mark Simpson, all former members of Radio 3's New Generation Artists scheme, join forces in an arrangement of a Faustian tale by Stravinsky and the recital concludes with Shostakovich's deeply felt second Piano Trio, written in the aftermath of the siege of Leningrad and the loss of a dear friend. Stravinsky: The Soldier's Tale Suite. Mark Simpson (clarinet), Atos Trio members - Annette von Hehn (violin), Thomas Hoppe (piano). Shostakovich: Piano Trio No 2. Atos Trio: Thomas Hoppe (piano), Annette von Hehn (violin), Stefan Heinemeyer (cello)

programme.title: Afternoon on 3
programme.desc: Rameau's Zoroastre, recorded at the Opera Berlioz Corum, Montpellier, as part of the Montpellier Festival. The story takes place in the ancient kingdom of Bactria and deals with the forces of Good, led by Zoroastre, contending with the forces of Evil, led by the sorcerer Abramane. Unusually for operas of the time the story is not taken from Classical mythology but from Persian religion. The historical Zoroaster was an important figure in Masonic circles and as with Mozart's The Magic Flute, there are obvious connections between the opera and Freemasonry. Presented by Penny Gore. Zoroastre: Reinoud van Mechelen (countertenor), Abramane: Nicolas Courjal (bass), Erinice: Emmanuelle de Negri (soprano), Amelite: Katherine Watson (soprano), Zopire/Oromases: Christian Immler (baritone), Cephie: Lea Desandre (mezzo-soprano), Pygmalion Ensemble, conductor Raphael Pichon. 2.00 Acts 1 and 2. 3.10 Act 3. 3.35 Acts 4 and 5

programme.title: Radio 3 in Concert
programme.sub-title: The LSO conducted by John Eliot Gardiner play Mendelssohn
programme.desc: Sir John Eliot Gardiner returns to the London Symphony Orchestra, accompanied by the Monteverdi Choir, for a programme dedicated to two of the most monumental pieces of Felix Mendelssohn's later career. Premiered two years before the composer's death in 1847, Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto is one of the great masterpieces of the violin repertoire, and his last large orchestral work. From the hauntingly beautiful opening motif, to scurrying arpeggios and fluttering tremolo, the concerto is a true display of the violinist's versatility. Coupled with this is the composer's symphony-cantata for orchestra and chorus, Lobgesang or Hymn of Praise (1840). With its stately grandeur and religiosity, it stands as another of his most impressive works. Presented by Sara Mohr-Pietsch, live from the Barbican Hall, London. Mendelssohn: Violin Concerto. 8.05 Interval. 8.25 Mendelssohn: Symphony No 2 ('Lobgesang'). Alina Ibragimova (violin), Lucy Crowe, soprano, Jurgita Adamontye, soprano, Michael Spyres, tenor, Monteverdi Choir, London Symphony Orchestra, conductor Sir John Eliot Gardiner

programme.title: Three Score and Ten
programme.desc: Ian McMillan with another episode in this fifty part series celebrating 70 years of Radio 3?s recording of poets and poetry since it was launched as the Third Programme in September 1946. From Radio 3's The Poet's Voice, broadcast in 1960, Vernon Scannell reads 'Dejection' and 'A Case of Murder'. Three Score and Ten features archive recordings from the last seven decades of the Third Programme and Radio 3, with 70 remarkable poets reading their own poems. Amongst them T.S. Eliot, Dylan Thomas, Sylvia Plath, WH Auden, Seamus Heaney and Carol Ann Duffy. Plus ten brand new poems by contemporary poets commissioned specially for the series and broadcast on The Verb

programme.title: Free Thinking
programme.desc: Artes Mundi was established in 2003 as a biennial contemporary visual arts initiative - we report on the exhibition opening in Cardiff this week which is showing work by the chosen artists John Akomfrah, Amy Franceschini/Future Farmers, Lamia Joreige, Neil Beloufa, Nastio Mosquito and Bedwyr Williams Artes Mundi 7 runs at the National Museum of Wales in Cardiff from 21.10.16 - 26.02.17

programme.title: The Essay: All My Presidents
programme.sub-title: Talkin' 'Bout my Generation; Bill Clinton and George W. Bush
programme.desc: What happens when political leaders are of your generation? Michael Goldfarb muses about two presidents, Bill Clinton and George W Bush, who share the same cultural influences - and flaws - as everybody else born in the years immediately following World War Two

programme.title: Composer of the Week: Coleridge-Taylor
programme.desc: When the composer died at the age of 37 in 1912, he was one of the most famous names in the musical world, thanks to the success of his choral masterpiece Hiawatha's Wedding Feast, the popularity of which lived on well into the 1920s and '30s. In the last of this week's programmes, Donald Macleod explores his final years, assesses his reputation today and presents a complete performance of his Violin Concerto. Coleridge-Taylor: Petite Suite de Concert, Op 77 - Un Sonnet D'Amour. Virginia Eskin (piano). Characteristic Waltzes, Op 22 - Valse Bohemienne. New Symphony Orchestra, conductor Malcolm Sargent. Hiawatha's Departure (excerpt). Helen Field (soprano), Bryn Terfel (baritone), Orchestra and Chorus of the Welsh National Opera, conductor Kenneth Alwyn. The Evening Star; Whispers of Summer. BBC Singers, conductor Paul Brough. Violin Concerto in G. Anthony Marwood, BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, conductor Martyn Brabbins

programme.title: Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert
programme.sub-title: Radio 3 Big Chamber Weekend: Cedars Hall
programme.desc: Fiona Talkington presents the final concert in this series, curated by Radio 3 in partnership with Cedars Hall at Wells Cathedral School, together with the Atos Trio. The group's musical journey around four European cities brings its members to Vienna, a centre of power and cultural influence for centuries. Viola player Philip Dukes joins the former Radio 3 New Generation Artists for a performance of Mozart's early Piano Quartet in G minor, and then the group plays Korngold's Piano Trio in D, written in Vienna, where Korngold was causing quite a stir at just 13 years of age, before he made his name as a film composer in Hollywood. Mozart: Piano Quartet in G minor Atos Trio Philip Dukes (viola), Korngold: Piano Trio in D, Op 1 Atos Trio

programme.title: Record Review
programme.desc: With Andrew McGregor. 9.30 Building a Library: Tess Knighton compares recordings of the 'Ensaladas' of the early sixteenth century Mateo Flecha and written for the diversion of courtiers. A captivating mixture of popular song, madrigal and liturgical music Flecha's lively Ensladas have in recent years attracted a range of performance styles, from one voice to a part to recordings with full choir and instruments. 10.30 David Owen Norris joins Andrew to discuss the recorded legacy of Emil Gilels, born a hundred years ago this week. One of the few Soviet musicians allowed to tour the west, Gilels had an extensive repertoire which ranged from the baroque to the works of Debussy, Rachmaninov and Prokofiev. David Owen Norris picks highlights from Deutsche Grammophon's 24 CD 'complete' recordings, a 7 CD set of RCA Red Seal and, more recently, a bumper 50 CD set from Melodiya

programme.desc: Julian Joseph with a performance by French jazz trumpeter Erik Truffaz and his quartet featuring Benoit Corboz (keyboard), Marcello Giuliani (electric bass) and drummer Arthur Hnatek. The quartet mix elements of jazz fusion, funk and hip-hop into their energetic live performances as can be heard on this set recorded at Cully Jazz Festival, Switzerland on the shores of Lake Geneva

programme.title: Opera on 3
programme.desc: Il Trovatore was one of the great trios of the operas Verdi wrote within a couple of years in the 1850's, along with Rigoletto and La Traviata. It was one of Verdi's most popular operas in his lifetime, and remains so today, with the Anvil Chorus one of the most well-known moments of the opera's 'gypsy' music. Zeljko Lucic (Count di Luna:Baritone), Lianna Haroutounian (Leonora:Soprano), Francesco Meli (Manrico:Tenor), Maurizio Muraro (Ferrando:Bass), Jennifer Davis (Ines:Soprano), David Junghoon Kim (Ruiz:Tenor), Royal Opera House Chorus, Royal Opera House Orchestra, Gianandrea Noseda (Conductor)

programme.title: Between the Ears: Between Ballard's Ears
programme.desc: J.G.Ballard's early fiction is full of sonorous surrealism. In this special edition of Between the Ears we go Between Ballard's Ears. Two new, specially commissioned, binaural adaptations of his work reveal the soundscape of one of Britain's greatest imaginations. In Track 12, adapted by Brian Sibley, two men listen in to the fantastically amplified results of microsonics but a different, deadlier game is underway. Anton Lesser and Elliot Levey star. In Venus Smiles, adapted by Frank Cottrell Boyce, an enigmatic artist's sonic sculpture brings chaos and transformation to the luxury resort of Vermilion Sands. Christine Bottomley, Carl Prekopp, Kezia Joseph & David Sterne star in a story of death and transfiguration. Sitar performed by Sheema Mukherjee. Sonic realization Mark Burman & Donald MacDonald. Directed & Produced by Mark Burman

programme.title: Hear and Now
programme.sub-title: Hannah Kendall's new opera The Knife of Dawn
programme.desc: Tom Service presents the world premiere of Hannah Kendall's opera The Knife of Dawn, recorded earlier this month at the Roundhouse in Camden, London. Plus music by Daniel Kidane, Samantha Fernando and A. N. Otherperson. The Knife of Dawn explores the life and mind of Guyanese poet and political activist Martin Carter as he fights for his country's independence from Britain. It's set in 1953, when Carter was imprisoned for 'spreading dissension'. In this, her operatic debut, Hannah Kendall sets five of Carter's own poems, 'In a Great Silence'; 'Listening to the Land'; 'This is the Dark Time My Love'; 'The Knife of Dawn' and 'Not Hands Like Mine', which have been drawn into a moving new libretto by Tessa McWatt

programme.title: Geoffrey Smith's Jazz
programme.desc: Duke Ellington made a speciality of musical portraits, evoking lovely ladies, showbiz stars, and Harlem?s local heroes. Among a selection of ducal masterworks, Geoffrey Smith includes tributes to Jack the Bear and Stompy Jones

Four more novels have followed and, most recently, What is Not Yours is Not Yours, a collection of short stories. She appeared on Granta's Best of Young British Novelists list in 2013

programme.title: Choral Evensong
programme.desc: Canon Marcus Huxley directs a performance of devotional music from Birmingham Cathedral. Introit: Jesu, the Very Thought of Thee (Harry Grindle). Responses: Byrd. Psalms 98, 99, 100, 101 (Attwood, Ouseley, Barnby). First Lesson: Hosea 14 vv 1-7. Office Hymn: O Trinity of Blessed Light (Creator alme). Canticles: Antony le Fleming. Second Lesson: 2 Timothy 4 vv 1-8. Anthem: The Wilderness (SS Wesley). Final Hymn: Soldiers of Christ, Arise (From Strength to Strength). Organ Voluntary: Sonata No 2 - third and fourth movements (Mendelssohn). Director of Music: Canon Marcus Huxley. Assistant Director of Music: David Hardie

programme.title: The Choir
programme.desc: Sara Mohr-Pietsch meets members of Jazzled, a community choir for sufferers of dementia and their carers. Director Mark De-lisser shares some of his favourite choral music

programme.title: The Listening Service
programme.desc: Tom Service delves into the dark side of Franz Schubert - what can we hear in his music? A provincial composer who died young, described as looking like a 'little mushroom' - on the face of it Franz Schubert doesn't seem a likely candidate for deep insight into the human condition. But appearances are very definitely deceptive, and some of his music can seem deceptively straightforward as well. Join Tom Service for a journey into Schubert's psyche and discover what his music tells us about the man, and perhaps about ourselves. With Dr Laura Tunbridge of Oxford University

programme.title: Words and Music
programme.desc: Olivia Williams and Michael Pennington read poetry and prose on the subject of hinterland, from the travel writing of Bruce Chatwin and Robert Byron to the sinister underworld of Virgil's Aeneid, via contemporary urban byways, childhood dreams and remote islands. Texts include poems by William Wordsworth, Christina Rossetti, Thomas Hardy and Robert Frost, alongside music by Debussy, Dowland, Reich, Mendelssohn, Bach and Britten

programme.title: Sunday Feature: The Other Third
programme.desc: Alan Dein explores the other voice of the Third Programme, not the plummy accent, or the rarefied readings and art music, but the articulate and expressive voice of so-called ordinary people, brought to the airwaves via a group of producers fascinated with everyday lives and the wild sounds they could collect beyond the confines of the radio studio. There's a significant omission to most studies of the life and times of the Third Programme. In the words of a title of one of the Third Programme's own history programmes, there are Gaps in the Record. The gap which the Third helped to fill through the work of figures like Douglas Cleverdon, Philip O'Connor, AL Lloyd, Alan Lomax and David Thomson, was to harness the stories of ordinary people's lives with a collection of creative and ground-breaking radio features and talks spanning the Third Programme's two decades. These programmes changed our conception of what radio should sound like and their influence continues in the programmes we hear today

programme.title: Radio 3 in Concert
programme.desc: Ian Skelly introduces a performance of Mahler's 8th Symphony conducted by Riccardo Chailly, in a concert recorded earlier this year at the Lucerne Festival. Mahler: Symphony No 8 in E flat (Symphony of a Thousand). Ricarda Merbeth (soprano), Juliane Banse (soprano), Anna Lucia Richter (soprano), Sara Mingardo (contralto), Mihoko Fujimura (mezzo-soprano), Andreas Schager (tenor), Peter Mattei (baritone), Samuel Youn (bass-baritone), Bavarian Radio Chorus, Latvian Radio Chorus, Talz Boys' Chorus, Lucerne Festival Orchestra, Riccardo Chailly (conductor)

programme.title: Drama on 3: Mary Rose
programme.desc: JM Barrie's haunting play about a sinister Scottish island and a girl who never grows up. A soldier sits staring into the fire in an empty, dark house while an unsettling and tragic history unfolds before him. Written in the aftermath of the First World War, Barrie's play about loss and the mystery of life is by turns comic, eerie and heartbreaking. Original music is composed and performed by Laura Moody, singer cellist. Laura was recently nominated for an Off-West End Theatre Award for her Sound Design of Dreamplay at The Vaults in Waterloo, London

programme.title: Early Music Late
programme.desc: Elin Manahan Thomas introduces a concert recorded earlier this year from in Belgium, given by the Czech consort L'Ensemble Inegal, directed by Adam Viktora, and featuring soprano soloist and cofounder of the ensemble Gabriela Eibenova The music transports us to eighteenth-century Germany, with a focus on Dresden, as a pearl of baroque eastern Germany at its pinnacle. The programme features the foremost composers of the Dresden Court

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: With Rob Cowan 9.00 Rob makes the first of his selections of favourite piano duos, including works by Mozart, Schubert, Bartok and Lutoslawski, as well as a magical vintage recording of a waltz by Arensky. 9.30 The daily musical challenge is to identify TV show or film that featured a certain piece of classical music. 10.00 Rob's guest this week is stand-up comedian Al Murray, who is best known for his alter ego the Pub Landlord, but has also presented history documentaries Road to Berlin and Al Murray's German Adventure. Al shares a selection of his favourite classical music, including works by Bach, Handel and Orff, and talks about playing percussion 10.30 The latest episode of Power of Three is followed by Music in Time, where the spotlight is on the late Renaissance era and Victoria's Requiem Mass, a work that seems to epitomise the sea-change in harmonic practice that was taking place around the turn of the 16th and 17th centuries 11.00 The artists of the week are the Academy of St Martin in the Fields, a superb gathering of players who can turn their hands to virtually any repertoire and make a handsome job of it.. Bartok: Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta, conductor Neville Marriner

programme.title: Composer of the Week: Michael Haydn
programme.desc: Donald Macleod explores the pre-Salzburg days of a man whose work is overshadowed by that of his much more acclaimed brother Joseph. Donald begins by looking at Michael's early years as a choral scholar with his older brother, and then in his first appointment to bishop Baron Adam Patachich in the town of Grosswardein. Michael Haydn: Symphony in D major, MH 287 - Finale. German Chamber Academy Neus, conductor Johannes Goritski. Sanctae Crucis, MH 56. Purcell Choir, Members of Orfeo Orchestra, conductor Gyorgy Vashegyi. Symphony in G, MH 26. Savaria Baroque Orchestra, conductor Pal Nemeth. Concerto in B flat for Violin, MH 36 - 1st movement. Barnabas Kelemen (violin), Erkel Ferenc Chamber Orchestra

programme.title: Radio 3 in Concert
programme.desc: Jamie MacDougall presents a recital from Glasgow's City Halls in which Ilan Volkov conducts the BBC SSO and Measha Brueggergosman in a performance of Kurt Weill's Seven Deadly Sins, alongside orchestral works by Busoni. Kurt Weill's Seven Deadly Sins was written to a libretto by Bertolt Brecht as a `sung ballet', and recounts the allegorical adventures of the title character Anna, as she explores life and all its temptations. Written in an evocative and recognizably Berlin-esque style, it evokes the heady turmoil of the interwar years with its jazz inflected banjo and close-harmony vocal group. group. The concert opens with two orchestral pieces by Italian composer Busoni, written at the turn of the century. Perhaps most famous for his epic piano works, this pair of orchestral scores demonstrates his melodic invention and contrapuntal detail with a wider instrumental palette. Busoni: Berceuse elegiaque. Busoni: 2 Studies for Doktor Faust. Weill: The Seven Deadly Sins. Measha Brueggergosman (soprano), Synergy Vocals, BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, conductor Ilan Volkov

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: Rob Cowan continues to revisit some of his favourite piano duos, including works by Mozart, Schubert, Bartok, Lutoslawski and Arensky. At 11.00, Rob's artists of the week are Neville Marriner's orchestra, the Academy of St Martin in the Fields. Tchaikovsky: Souvenir de Florence, Op 70. programme.desc: John Toal introduces performances by Radio 3 New Generation Artists at the Belfast International Arts Festival. Recorded in the Naughton Studio of Belfast's Lyric Theatre, pianist Pavel Kolesnikov appears as soloist in Beethoven's Bagatelles, Op 33 and accompanist in a selection of Haydn songs, performed by fellow Radio 3 New Generation Artist, baritone Benjamin Appl. The programme ends with Hindemith's five-movement Kleine Kammermusik, Op 24 No 2. It features New Generation Artist Alec Frank-Gemmill - Principal Horn with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra - alongside fellow SCO wind players. Beethoven: Bagatelles, Op 33. Pavel Kolesnikov (piano). Haydn: Selected Songs: The Mermaid's Song, HobXXVIa25 (Hunter); She Never Told Her Love, HobXXVIa34 (Shakespeare); The Sailor's Song, HobXXVIa31 (Hunter); Liebes Madchen, hor mir zu, HobXXVIaD1 (anonymous); The Spirit's Song, HobXXVIa41 (Hunter). Benjamin Appl (baritone), Pavel Kolesnikov (piano). Hindemith: Kleine Kammermusik, Op 24 No 2 (Wind Quintet). Juliette Bausor (flute), Robin Williams (oboe), Maximiliano Martin (clarinet), Peter Whelan (bassoon), Alec Frank-Gemmill (horn)

programme.title: Radio 3 in Concert
programme.sub-title: BBC Philharmonic: Shostakovich, Nielsen and Maxwell Davies
programme.desc: The BBC Philharmonic, conducted by John Storgards, play powerful music by Shostakovich, Nielsen and Maxwell Davies, joined by virtuoso trumpeter Hakan Hardenberger. The Overture to Nielsen's Maskarade sets the scene for a masked ball, full of vivacious energy and playful wit. Shostakovich's hugely powerful Tenth Symphony received its first performance soon after Stalin died and its opening movement speaks bleakly of suffering while the Scherzo snarls with venom. Pioneering trumpeter Hakan Hardenberger is the soloist in Peter Maxwell Davies's Concerto, with its virtuoso solo demands and rich orchestral palette. A still, calm voice here is the plainsong quoted by the composer celebrating the feast of St Francis. The sounds of birds feature too, familiar from Max's Orkney home, rather than from Assisi. Presented by Tom Redmond from the Bridgewater Hall, Manchester. Hakan Hardenberger (trumpet), BBC Philharmonic, conductor John Storgards. Nielsen: Overture: Maskarade. Maxwell Davies: Trumpet Concerto. 8.10 Music Interval. 8.30 Shostakovich: Symphony No 10

programme.title: Three Score and Ten
programme.desc: Ian McMillan presents a 50-part series celebrating 70 years of Radio 3's recording of poets and poetry since it was launched as the Third Programme in September 1946. programme.title: Free Thinking
programme.sub-title: Richard Hakluyt; Man Booker Prize; Chickens in the Anthropocene; Shirley Jackson
programme.desc: Nandini Das talks to Matthew Sweet about the life and legacy of Richard Hakluyt, the 17th-century explorer and writer whose work promoted colonisation of North America by the English. Also includes a report from the prize ceremony for this year's Man Booker Prize, and discuss new research into the signficance of chickens in the anthropocene and ahead of Halloween we look at the haunting writing of Shirley Jackson as a new biography of her life is published

programme.title: The Stroma Sessions
programme.desc: New drama. The Blackletter Quartet, a new music ensemble, had an idea: to write and record an album on Stroma, an abandoned island off the north coast of Scotland. Five years after the Quartet's disappearance, The Stroma Sessions, a series of audio files charting the musicians time on the island and the music they created there - were discovered on the internet. Stroma was abandoned in the early 1960s: its few remaining buildings stand dilapidated, battered by the North Sea. The four musicians sought inspiration in the ruined houses and unforgiving weather. They wanted to make music in a ghost town. The evidence suggests they found what they were looking for. The appearance of an unexpected outsider and the mysterious recording at the church have created unease amongst the musicians

programme.title: Green Cities from Bricks and Mortar
programme.desc: Dan Cruickshank considers whether the Government's proposed new Garden Cities programme could really be the answer to Britain's housing crisis. Originally pioneered by Ebenezer Howard in 1898, garden cities were conceived as an antidote to an overcrowded and overpopulated London. Designed to combine the best elements of both urban and rural life, they were intended as a philosophical solution as a practical one, but Dan wonders whether this idyllic Victorian solution may prove to be a blight on modern lifestyles and landscapes

programme.desc: Melvyn Bragg and guests discuss the changes in the intellectual world of Western Europe in the 12th century, and their origins. This was a time of Crusades, the formation of states, the start of Gothic architecture, a reconnection with Roman and Greek learning and their Arabic development and the start of the European universities, and has become known as the 12th Century Renaissance

programme.desc: Nicholas Wapshott tells the story of how American director Martin Scorsese unwittingly acted as Cupid in the unlikely romance between his boyhood hero, the celebrated British director Michael Powell, and his film editor Thelma Schoonmaker, when he introduced the pair in 1980. They fell in love and were married until Powell's death in 1994. Scorsese recalls that meeting and also reassesses Powell's work on such movies as The Red Shoes and The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp

The death of the empress's father threatens the security of Shonagon's position at court. Ruth Gemmell stars. Broadcast earlier as part of Woman's Hour

programme.title: Searching for Tobias
programme.desc: In 2008, Chloe Hadjimatheou was covering Barak Obama's first election campaign when she met a 15-year-old black boy in a Mississippi trailer park who had dreams of becoming a policeman. Eight years later, Chloe goes in search of him to find what became of him. Did Tobias ever fulfil his wishes and he has he prospered in Obama's America

programme.title: Analysis
programme.desc: In popular imagination, being in a crowd makes people scary and irrational. But is this true? David Edmonds asks social psychologists - including expert on groups Steve Reicher - about the psychology of crowds and looks at the implications for how gatherings of people are policed

programme.title: Natural Histories

programme.desc: David Attenborough presents the songs and calls of the Australian magpie, which looks like the European species but is not related. Groups of the birds take part in a behaviour known as carolling, during which they make calls that mark their territories and cement relationships

programme.title: The Reith Lectures: Mistaken Identities
programme.desc: Philosopher and cultural theorist Kwame Anthony Appiah argues against a mythical and romantic view of nationhood, saying instead it should rest on a commitment to shared values. He explores the history of the idea, born in the 19th century, that there are peoples who are bound together by an ancient common spirit and that each of these nations is entitled to its own state

programme.title: Woman's Hour
programme.desc: Lively discussion and interviews, presented by Jane Garvey. Including at 10.45 the 15 Minute Drama: part two of the ninth series of The Pillow Book, by Robert Forrest

programme.title: Natural Histories
programme.desc: Brett Westwood explores the human relationship with the toad, a creature long derided as ugly, poisonous, warty and grumpy and has also been viewed as an evil spirit. He reveals how Kenneth Grahame did his best to dispel many of these myths when he introduced his readers to the loveable rascal Mr Toad in Wind in the Willows, and learns about the huge number of volunteers venturing out every year to gather toads from roads and release them in nearby pools and lakes to breed once again

programme.title: Soul Music
programme.sub-title: The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face
programme.desc: Memories of love, children and loss are stirred by The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face, the timeless love song written by Ewan MacColl for Peggy Seeger, and made famous by Roberta Flack. With contributions by Peggy Seeger, Ben Harker, Jason King, Louise Janson, Kandace Springs, and Julie Young

programme.title: Costing the Earth
programme.desc: Some of the last refuges of the orang-utan are under threat. As food manufacturers demand more palm oil for their processed products so the pressure grows on the forests of Indonesia which contain some the last of the orang-utan and some of the world's densest reserves of carbon capturing peat. Peter Hadfield travels to Indonesia to witness the forest being cleared and the peat being burnt

programme.title: Hoboing with Honeyboy
programme.desc: Journalist Gianluca Tramontana looks back at the life and work of Mississsippi Delta blues musician David `Honeyboy' Edwards, who died in August 2011. Regarded as the last link to the origins of the genre, Edwards began his career as a teenager in the Great Depression of the late 1920s and early 1930s, and went on to play with stars including Robert Johnson, Charlie Patton, Son House and Sonny Boy Williamson. Tramontana also explores the musician's nomadic lifestyle by travelling across the USA, visiting New York, Mississippi and the National Hobo Convention in Iowa, as well as Chicago - the city where Edwards settled following the Second World War

programme.title: Holloway Dreams: The Joe Meek Story
programme.desc: Tom Robinson profiles the pioneering Sixties record producer responsible for introducing futuristic sounds into the textures of modern pop. Despite having no musical training, he developed the now familiar techniques of reverb and compression and gave America its first number one single by a British band with Telstar by the Tornadoes. Wildly eccentric and secretive, he led a chaotic personal life which ended in tragedy. First broadcast in 2007

programme.title: The Full Works Concert
programme.desc: Jane Jones pays tribute to pianist Emil Gilels, 100 years after his birth, and features works by Borodin, Beethoven, Tchaikovsky, Mozart and Glazunov. Borodin: Prince Igor - Polovtsian Dances. Philadelphia Orchestra and Choir, conductor Eugene Ormandy. Beethoven: Piano Sonata No.8 in C minor Opus 13 ÂPathetique'. Emil Gilels (piano). Tchaikovsky: Variations on a Rococo Theme Opus 33. Mstislav Rostropovich (cello), Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, conductor Hebert von Karajan. Mozart: Concerto for 2 Pianos in E-flat major K.365. Emil Gilels (piano 1), Elena Gilels (piano 2), Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, conductor Karl Bohm. Glazunov: Meditation Opus 32. Leonid Kogan (violin), USSR Academic Symphony Orchestra, conductor Evgeny Svetlanov. Rachmaninov: Variations on a theme of Corelli Opus 42 (Arranged for orchestra). Detroit Symphony Orchestra, conductor Neeme Jarvi

Elin Manahan Thomas (soprano), Bryn Terfel (bass-baritone), Catrin Finch (harpist), Joo Yeon Sir (violin), David Childs (euphonium), Karl Jenkins conducts a mixed choir of over 150, with a children's choir of 116 and Sinfonia Cymru

programme.title: The Full Works Concert
programme.desc: The Royal Scottish National Orchestra, the UK's third oldest professional orchestra, has been celebrating its 125th anniversary in 2016. Tonight, Jane Jones presents a concert given just a week ago, where British pianist Paul Lewis teamed up with conductor Cristian Macelaru and the RSNO to perform Beethoven's much loved Piano Concerto No.5 (ÂEmperor'). Also on the bill is Dvorak's Seventh Symphony. Beethoven: Piano Concerto No.5 in E-flat Op 73 (ÂEmperor'). Paul Lewis (piano), Royal Scottish National Orchestra, conductor Cristian Macelaru. Dvorak: Symphony No.7 in D minor Op 70. Royal Scottish National Orchestra, conductor Cristian Macelaru. Vaughan Williams: Bucolic Suite. Royal Scottish National Orchestra, conductor Martin Yates. Saint-Saens: Romance Op 37. Katherine Bryan (flute), Royal Scottish National Orchestra, conductor Jac van Steen
